1214.13.text:
Use the platform to
build great apps.

1216.04.text:
Use what the browser
gives you to achieve

1218.02.text:
minimal payload, minimal
overhead, design offline-first.

1223.65.text:
And this is a hard
challenge, and so we

1225.68.text:
wanted to make this
easier to use the platform

1228.19.text:
to build cutting edge,
progressive web applications.

1231.82.text:
So I'm really excited today
to announce the Polymer App

1243.48.text:
And the Toolbox is just a set

1249.25.text:
make it easy to build
cutting edge progressive web

1254.25.text:
Well, all the things you'd

for routing, for

All UI design

So a very simple tool that

Now let's say we

And we want to store data

on the device to then

And again, we wanted to provide

to take data from the cloud,

provide it to an application

1759.47.text:
And what app-storage
is is it's essentially

1761.33.text:
an interface that allows
you, the developer,

1763.56.text:
to create your own web
component to connect data

1766.39.text:
from any service, whether
it's in the cloud,

1768.22.text:
whether it's on the device,
and service that data in a way

1773.03.text:
And the way app-storage
storage services

1774.70.text:
the data is in a very
platform idiomatic way.

1776.64.text:
That data is serviced just as
a property on the DOM node.

1779.87.text:
And any changes to that data
are expressed as DOM events.

1783.83.text:
And conveniently, that's exactly
how Polymer's own data binding

1788.43.text:
Very much uses the platform,
so it's available there

1792.46.text:
And so app-storage provides

1795.27.text:
with Polymer's own
data binding system.

1797.53.text:
So let's give an example
of how you might use this.

1799.65.text:
Say you're building a note
taking progressive web app.

You're going to want to launch
it from your Home screen

1803.79.text:
because, of course, it's

You can add titles
to your notes.

You can add information
and details to your notes.

1809.10.text:
And all of this data you're
going to store in a REST API

1811.66.text: that you've built in the cloud.

1813.56.text:
But of course, it's a
progressive web app,

1815.40.text:
so it needs to be
able to work offline.

1817.88.text:
So if we go offline, launch
it from our Home screen,

1820.05.text:
if we're just relying on getting
the data from our REST API,

1824.35.text:
we're not going to be
able to launch the data,

1827.43.text:
We're not going to have
access to the internet

1831.85.text:
But app-storage makes it very
easy to architect your app

1834.26.text:
so that you can support
this use case very simply.

1837.62.text:
So here's how we're
going to build it.

1839.93.text:
You're going to build
your own component that

1845.55.text:
And that's going to
manage communicating

1847.23.text: with the REST API in the cloud.

1849.75.text:
And then you're going to use a
component, app-indexdb-mirror,

1852.29.text:
that we've provided as part
of the app-storage components.

1854.33.text:
And what that does is take any
data that's passed through it,

1857.04.text:
and it mirrors it into a
local indexdb instance.

1860.05.text:
And then that's going to pass
data into your application.

1864.29.text:
So here's how it looks when
all the data is wired up.

1866.50.text:
When you're online,
your cloud API component

1868.82.text:
has no problem interfacing
with your REST API.

1872.95.text:
It's going to pipe that data
through this app-indexdb-mirror

1875.45.text:
component, which is then going
to pipe the data to your app.

1881.56.text:
When you go offline,
your cloud API component

1884.88.text:
can no longer communicate
with its rest endpoint.

1888.29.text:
But since we've been
piping all of that data

1892.98.text:
we have all of
that locally stored

1894.64.text:
in an indexdb instance
on our device.

1896.52.text:
And so we can boot up
our application even

1902.19.text:
But what if you don't want

1904.48.text:
What if you don't want

1906.97.text:
What if you wanted to

1909.38.text: as a service in the cloud?

for that-- the app-storage

and to use that data

1939.92.text: We can lay out our application.

1941.31.text:
We can route between
different views.

1944.78.text:
We can communicate with the
back end and store data.

1947.98.text:
But we still need to deliver
this application to our users.

1952.01.text:
And remember, this
is the mobile web.

1959.24.text:
We maximum efficiency
to be able to minimize

1962.93.text:
the time to first meaningful
interaction for our users.

1966.24.text: And this is the great challenge.

1967.62.text:
How do you minimize that time
to first meaningful interaction?

1974.93.text:
We can use the same old
JavaScript escape hatches.

1977.01.text:
We can build a massive tool
chain with use of JavaScript.

1980.27.text:
We can get a fast first paint
with our server-side rendered

1982.95.text:
app, and then download
the meta platform,

1984.66.text:
and then boot it up, and
then make it interactive.

1987.77.text:
But it's frustrating
for a user to sit

1990.74.text:
And it's even more
frustrating, as a developer,

1992.93.text:
to jump through all these
hoops to server-side render

1995.28.text:
to, at the end of the day,
only really have generated

1997.53.text: a splash screen or a spinner.

2000.03.text:
And time to first splash
screen, time to first spinner,

2002.97.text:
is not the same thing as time
to first meaningful interaction.

2007.23.text:
So server-side rendering like
this to deliver an application,

2011.19.text:
whether you get an
app view or a spinner,

2014.71.text:
Your user still has to
wait for your abstraction

2016.71.text:
to load before your
application is useful.

2020.57.text:
We think there is a better way,
which is to use the platform

2027.00.text:
The tighter the platform you
can build your application,

2029.33.text:
the faster it's going to be,
especially on slow networks

2033.91.text:
Let the browser be
your application.

2036.55.text:
And thanks to brand new
web platform primitives,

2039.27.text:
we can throw out a lot of
the old knowledge about how

2041.88.text:
to make an application
fast on mobile

2043.63.text:
and embrace new primitives
and technologies

2048.62.text:
So there are really three
important primitives

2051.46.text:
for delivering a modern
mobile application-- web

2055.53.text:
components, which allow you to
construct your application out

2060.63.text:
of these granular components;
HTTP/2 and Server Push, which

2065.46.text:
allows you to serve these
granular dependencies

2067.56.text:
in a granular way to your users
without incurring massive round

2071.43.text:
trips and to most efficiently
utilize the bandwidth;

2075.90.text:
and then Service Worker,
which lets you reliably

2078.37.text:
cache these granular components
on your user's device.

2083.32.text:
So let's take a look at how
these three primitives work

2087.66.text:
So let's say we're
building an app.

2094.94.text:
They share some similar
UI between the views.

2099.59.text:
If we built this the old way, as
an old-school, single page app,

2103.99.text:
for each of these views, no
matter what route the user hit,

2108.55.text:
this monolithic app.js, this
monolithic framework and a CSS

2111.69.text:
We'd send all of them
down to the client.

2113.58.text:
And then on the
client, the framework

2115.44.text:
Then the application
would have to boot up.

2116.71.text:
Then it would have to match
the route to the view,

2118.15.text:
and then it would have
to render that view.

2123.41.text: But let's take a step back.

2129.42.text:
Some overlap in terms
of what they actually

2132.89.text:
Let's use the platform
to serve this application

2139.23.text: So let's split the view down.

2140.44.text:
Let's break it down into
individual web components.

2142.79.text:
Some of these
components are going

2145.34.text:
Some are going to be unique
to a particular view.

2148.57.text:
Let's say the user
requests this / route.

2152.27.text:
The server can know
exactly what components

2154.86.text:
are needed in order
to render that view

2157.48.text:
and to make it
usable on the device.

2160.60.text:
And so the server can
use HTTP/2 and Server

2162.64.text:
Push to push down exactly
the minimal dependencies,

2165.61.text:
the minimal components that
are needed to make that route,

2168.30.text:
to make that view interactive
without multiple round trips.

2172.48.text:
And then we have that
there on a device

2174.21.text:
that the user can
start interacting

2176.83.text:
And not only that, we can take
those granular components,

2180.49.text:
and we can stick them in
the Service Worker cache.

2184.17.text:
And then in the
background, as the user

2186.15.text:
is interacting with
that first view,

2188.09.text:
the Service Worker
can start fetching

2190.20.text:
additional granular
components from the network

2194.95.text:
It can get those
from the network

2196.32.text:
and stick those too in
its Service Worker cache.

2201.46.text:
So that if the user then
navigates to the next view,

2204.32.text:
/items, there's a good chance
that you'll already have every

2207.73.text:
single component that you need
to render in that view and make

2210.46.text:
it interactive already right
there sitting in your cache.

2213.76.text:
You don't have to go
to the network at all.

2215.55.text:
But of course, it's not
practical to necessarily cache

2218.49.text:
every single dependency for
your entire application.

2221.72.text:
So for future views,
you can lazily

2223.42.text:
load and lazily instantiate
additional components that you

2228.09.text:
And of course, some
of those might already

2229.84.text:
be sitting there
right in your cache.

2231.38.text:
And for those that aren't,
you can use the server

2233.85.text:
to push down only the
minimal set of dependencies

2236.31.text:
that the user doesn't
already have in their cache.

2241.05.text:
So there's a pattern
starting to emerge here.

2244.09.text:
You push components that are
needed for your initial route.

2248.08.text:
You render that initial
route and make it interactive

2252.58.text:
You precache in the
background using

2258.61.text:
And then you lazy-load and
create future routes on demand

2262.19.text: as the user navigates to them.

2264.69.text:
And we really like acronyms
on the Polymer Project,

2267.62.text:
so we've been calling
this the PRPL pattern.

2271.69.text:
And the PRPL pattern is
not Polymer-specific.

2274.02.text:
It's just a pattern
for progressively

2275.62.text:
loading and rendering a
modern, progressive web

2278.32.text:
app using these new technologies
and primitives in the web

2283.74.text:
So with the PRPL
pattern, you get

2292.13.text:
And the crux of
this PRPL pattern

2294.07.text:
is the ability to break
up your application

2298.48.text:
require minimal overhead
themselves to boot up.

2301.14.text:
And that's exactly what
web components provides.

2306.87.text:
So now that we're armed
with the PRPL pattern

2308.74.text:
and we've built
our app, how do we

2310.16.text:
apply it to our own
progressive web app

2311.96.text:
that we're building

2315.35.text:
Now, there are a lot
of different tools

2317.06.text:
for building and optimizing

2320.78.text:
And we wanted a
maximally simple tool

2323.22.text:
to make it easy to get started

this pattern, to develop,
and then ultimately

2329.56.text:
And so we built the Polymer CLI,
the Polymer Command Line Tool.

2340.87.text:
And the goal of the Polymer CLI
is to stay focused and simple.

2345.58.text:
It provides just a
few set of commands

2348.16.text:
that can help support
you throughout

2349.66.text:
the entire development
experience, whether you're

2351.60.text:
building a Polymer
component or whether you're

2353.52.text:
building an entire application
out of web components.

2357.82.text:
So this includes
polymer init, which

2360.52.text:
makes it really easy to scaffold
out an initial web component

or an entire application built
out of these web components.

2367.64.text:
And it'll set up
the folder structure

2369.18.text:
that you need for
each of these too.

2370.68.text:
And we've also built a
set of starter templates

2372.69.text:
to get you started with
different types of applications

2374.98.text: that you might want to build.

2378.05.text:
Polymer serve will locally
serve your application

2380.63.text:
or your component
so that you can

2382.00.text: play with it as you develop.

2383.55.text:
And what's cool about polymer
serve is that not only will it

2389.52.text:
it will also serve all of the
documentation automatically

2394.73.text:
that you're using to
build your application.

2396.63.text:
So you can develop and
on a second browser tab,

2400.03.text:
you can have all
the documentation

2401.45.text:
for the components
you're using to develop.

2402.79.text:
So it's a really
great experience.

2411.77.text:
Polymer lint will lint
your code and check

2414.74.text:
for common errors that
occur when you're building

2419.37.text:
And then polymer build well let
us specify a main entry point

2426.83.text:
And it will generate a
bundled and unbundled version

2429.56.text:
of your application
that you can then serve.

2431.99.text:
The unbundled version
is perfect for serving

2436.51.text:
so that you can use the
PRPL pattern to send them

2440.51.text:
But we also generate
a bundled version

2443.13.text:
for a fallback for browsers
that don't yet support HTTP/2.

2447.85.text:
And polymer build also
uses a tool called

2449.57.text:
service worker precache
to generate these Service

2452.38.text:
Workers that do this precaching,
prefetching, and sticking

2456.03.text:
these components in
the cache for you

2457.94.text:
so that if you
don't want to, you

2458.73.text:
don't have to write a line
of Service Worker code.

2460.37.text:
All of this is generated for
you based on your application.

2469.51.text:
So that's the Toolbox-- layout,
routing, localization, storage,

2473.40.text:
and a command line tool
to tie it all together.

2476.34.text:
And you might be
thinking, Didn't we

2480.46.text:
Didn't we just build
another monolithic stack?

2485.62.text:
In fact, it's not
a stack at all.

2488.51.text:
It is just a set of loosely
coupled, interoperable web

2492.43.text:
components that can
be used piecemeal,

2500.17.text:
And each of these components
is just a lightweight layer

2503.24.text:
on top of platform primitives
that already exist right there

2509.85.text:
So with the Polymer
App Toolbox, we're

2512.41.text:
showing that you don't need
a massive meta platform.

2514.87.text:
You don't need a
massive mega framework.

2516.79.text:
You don't need an
alternate platform

2518.29.text:
to build a high-quality
mobile web application.

2520.86.text:
You don't need
tons of JavaScript.

2522.31.text:
You don't need a crazy,
complex tool chain to serve it.

2525.94.text:
You just need to
use the platform

2527.92.text:
and use all the
modern primitives

2533.06.text:
Now, of course, we
didn't want this to just

2537.74.text:
So we built an app using
all of these techniques.

2545.83.text:
It doesn't actually
sell Google gear,

2547.45.text:
so you can't check
out and buy anything.

2549.12.text:
So don't expect anything
to show up at your door.

2551.21.text:
But it's got all the views
for a typical e-commerce app.

2553.54.text:
It's got a Main splash
page, a Home page.

2555.27.text: It's got a Product Listing view.

2558.27.text:
and it's got a Cart
and a Check Out flow.

2562.49.text:
And it's built and served
using all of these components,

2565.21.text:
using all of these patterns--
web components, Service Worker,

2569.09.text:
And it uses Polymer
and the app elements,

2571.00.text:
and the Polymer CLI
to develop and build.

2575.05.text:
So you can check out this
demo as well as everything

2577.78.text:
that's in the Toolbox, and
documentation about all

2579.86.text:
the things that are in the
Toolbox at the brand new

2590.41.text:
So in summary, the
Polymer Project's approach

2593.87.text:
to modern web
development is different.

2596.11.text:
It's different than that of a
typical JavaScript framework

2601.55.text:
It uses what's already
there in users' browsers

2604.30.text:
rather than creating
massive abstractions on top.

2606.99.text:
And why is it important to use
the platform for performance

2611.78.text:
And thanks to these new,
powerful, web platform

2615.74.text:
This is finally possible
as web developers

2617.53.text:
to create these kinds of
engaging, immersive, app-like

2621.91.text:
And so the result of
using the platform

2624.11.text:
is a first class,
progressive web app built out

2632.02.text:
So if you'd like to
learn more about Polymer,

2633.95.text:
or web components,
or the PRPL pattern,

2636.37.text:
there are tons more
talks here at Google I/O

2640.06.text:
Progressive, Performant Polymer
is right after this one.

2645.29.text:
And if you have time
machine or a YouTube,

2647.41.text:
you can check out the talks that
have already happened earlier.

2653.69.text: So I'm really excited by this.

2658.36.text:
And if you'd like to
learn more about Polymer,

2660.51.text:
about progressive web apps,
about the PRPL pattern,

2666.38.text:
The next Polymer
Summit, which will

2668.30.text: be later this year in London.

2676.49.text:
So you can sign up at
this link to be notified

2679.93.text:
If it's anything like
last year's Polymer Summit

2681.96.text:
that we held in Amsterdam,
it's going to be awesome.

2684.76.text:
There are 800 developers
in a beautiful venue.

2687.11.text:
It was a full day of talks
and native code labs,

2689.18.text:
and I'm really excited
to do it all again.

2695.14.text:
I hope to see you at
the Polymer Summit.
